Letter to Client 
Table of Contents
Dear [name of trustee]:I am writing regarding the [name of disabled beneficiary]'s Special Needs Trust Agreement dated [month] [day], [year] (the "Trust"), which we [have prepared / reviewed upon your request].The purpose of this letter is to (1) describe the process of transferring assets into the trust; and (2) discuss what you, as trustee of the Trust, need to address during administration of the Trust. Please keep this letter for future reference.To accomplish the long-term goals for which the trust was created, the trustee must adhere to the terms in the trust document and the tax laws relating to trusts. If you have any questions about the tax laws relating to this trust, please do not hesitate to ask me or the person who prepares the tax returns for the Trust.The Trust describes the powers and duties of the trustee(s). Since not all trust documents (also called trust instruments) contain the same powers, closely review and familiarize yourself with the Trust terms to be certain of your authority, requirements imposed upon you, and options for taking action on behalf of the Trust. Reach out to me with questions about the Trust terms as you review them.The Trust is a First-Party Special Needs Trust, designed to hold assets while preserving [name of disabled beneficiary]'s ability to receive government benefits. The principal government benefit in Illinois to which [name of disabled beneficiary] is entitled is called Medical Assistance. Transfers to the Trust can consist of cash, bonds, shares of stock, real property, or personal property, etc., but it is important to note that no additions to the trust can be made on or after the 65th birthday of [name of disabled beneficiary]. Also, once assets are transferred to the Trust, [name of disabled beneficiary] has no control of, right to demand, or ability to withdraw any assets from the Trust.1. Irrevocability of Trust. The trust is an irrevocable trust and cannot be amended, except under limited circumstances to conform with federal or state law. Please contact me if you believe this may be an issue at any time during the administration of the trust.2. Federal Tax Identification Number. Obtain a taxpayer identification number (TIN) for the Trust from the Internal Revenue Service by filing IRS Form SS-4. The TIN serves to keep the trust assets separate from those of the settlor and identifies the trust in bank accounts and tax returns. Do not use your own social security number or the disabled beneficiary's social security number. The Trust must have its own TIN.3. Trust Funding. The ownership of one or more assets must be transferred to the trustee for the trust to be in effect. The bank or brokerage account or the asset itself, such as shares of stock, should be titled in the name of the trust, as follows: "[Name of trustee], Trustee of The [Name of disabled beneficiary] Special Needs Trust dated [month] [day] [year]." (Some banks may want to use a slightly different name.)To transfer funds from checking, savings, and brokerage accounts, the TIN should be provided. A bank or brokerage firm may request a copy of the signed trust instrument for examination by the firm's legal department. We generally do not provide a copy of the entire agreement. A copy of the signature page and the trustee powers will serve to demonstrate that the trust has been properly executed and the trustee has the necessary power to borrow money, buy and sell stocks, bonds, and options, trade on margin, and conduct other trust business. A certification of trust prepared in accordance with Illinois law may also sometimes be used in lieu of the entire trust agreement.To transfer real estate into the trust, a deed must be executed and recorded granting the property to the trust. We can prepare the deed for the property for signature by [name of disabled beneficiary / name of guardian]. Upon obtaining the necessary signatures, we will record the deed at the county Recorder of Deeds office. You should contact the homeowner's insurance company to notify them of the title change. 4. Taxation of Trust Income. File the IRS Form 1041 and  Form IL -1041 to report the income for any year in which the trust has taxable income. These forms are due on April 15 of the year after receipt of the taxable income. We strongly recommend retaining an accountant for preparation of tax returns.5. Distributions from the Trust. The Trust was created to provide [name of disabled beneficiary] with supplemental means of support in addition to, not as replacement of, [name of disabled beneficiary]'s government benefits. Accordingly, the types of distributions that can be made to support the disabled beneficiary are limited. In general, distributions should not be made for basic support, which includes (1) housing (e.g., mortgage, real property taxes, rent, etc.); (2) utilities (e.g., gas, electricity, water, sewer, waste service, etc.) (3) food; (4) clothing; and (5) medical treatment for which public or Medicaid funds are available. The government benefits are meant to cover these expenses and any payment of them using the Trust's funds could result in the loss of benefits. All distributions from the Trust are at the discretion of the trustee. Here are some examples of items for which distributions are permissible:(a) phone, cable, and internet service(b) entertainment (e.g., concerts, museums, theater, movies, tickets to sports events, subscriptions)(c) furniture(d) computer hardware and software (e) education expenses unrelated to room and board (i.e., tuition, books, computers, supplies)(f) medical equipment not covered by any other benefit(g) travel(h) nonfood grocery items (e.g., cleaning supplies, personal hygiene products, tissues) (i) eyeglasses –and– (j) automobile expensesCash or cash equivalents should not be distributed directly to the beneficiary, even if they are reimbursements or prepayments for acceptable expenditures. Instead, payments should be made directly to third parties. Distributions also should not be made to or for the benefit of anyone other than the beneficiary.If you have any questions about permissible distributions, please do not hesitate to contact me.6. Recordkeeping. Please keep detailed records of the trust assets, income, and expenditures (including the date, amount, payee, and purpose). You may be required to provide a detailed accounting of the Trust to the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services (IDHFS) upon the termination of the Trust.7. Yearly Statement of Claims. Under Illinois law, the Trust is required to contain a  provision that provides for reimbursement to the IDHFS, upon the death of the disabled  beneficiary, of an amount equal to the total amount of Medical Assistance paid on  behalf of the trust beneficiary. You, as trustee, will receive an annual statement of claims  (SOC) to show the current amount owed to the IDHFS. The SOC will contain a running total  of all medical bills paid on behalf of [name of disabled beneficiary] since the execution of  the Trust.8. Reimbursement to the DHS. If the trust is terminated or [name of disabled beneficiary] dies, you, as trustee, must notify the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services.  At that time, the SNT Depository will provide a final comprehensive SOC to you, showing the total reimbursement owed to the DHS. If the IDHFS will not be fully reimbursed from the Trust, a final accounting of the SNT funds should accompany the payment.9. Termination of the Trust. The trust will terminate if either of the following events occur:• There are no more assets in the trust.• The disabled beneficiary dies and the assets of the trust, after any required reimbursement to the IDHFS for the total amount of medical assistance paid on behalf of [name of disabled beneficiary], are distributed to the beneficiary's descendants or the other contingent beneficiaries named in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust.10. Trustee Powers. A detailed list of the trustee's powers can be found in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust. Please make sure you understand them. I am happy to answer any questions you may have about them.I hope that this letter has answered your immediate questions. If you would like further explanation of any aspect of funding or administering the trust, please do not hesitate to contact me.
Sincerely,____________________[name of attorney]End of Document

Letter to Client 
Table of Contents
Dear [name of client]:I am writing regarding the [name of disabled beneficiary]'s Special Needs Trust Agreement dated [month] [day], [year] (the "Trust"), which we [have prepared / reviewed upon your request].The purpose of this letter is to (1) describe the process of transferring assets into the trust; and (2) discuss what you, as trustee of the Trust, need to address during administration of the Trust. Please keep this letter for future reference.To accomplish the long-term goals for which the trust was created, the trustee must adhere to the terms in the trust document and the tax laws relating to trusts. If you have any questions about the tax laws relating to this trust, please do not hesitate to ask me or the person who prepares the tax returns for the Trust.The Trust describes the powers and duties of the trustee(s). Since not all trust documents (also called trust instruments) contain the same powers, closely review and familiarize yourself with the Trust terms to be certain of your authority, requirements imposed upon you, and options for taking action on behalf of the Trust. Reach out to me with questions about the Trust terms as you review them.The Trust is a First-Party Special Needs Trust, designed to hold assets while preserving [name of disabled beneficiary]'s ability to receive government benefits. The principal government benefit in Ohio to which [name of disabled beneficiary] is entitled is called Medicaid. Transfers to the Trust can consist of cash, bonds, shares of stock, real property, or personal property, etc., but it is important to note that no additions to the trust can be made on or after the 65th birthday of [name of disabled beneficiary]. Also, once assets are transferred to the Trust, [name of disabled beneficiary] has no control of, right to demand, or ability to withdraw any assets from the Trust.1. Irrevocability of Trust. The trust is an irrevocable trust and cannot be amended, except under limited circumstances to conform with federal or state law. Please contact me if you believe this may be an issue at any time during the administration of the trust.2. Federal Tax Identification Number. Obtain a taxpayer identification number (TIN) for the Trust from the Internal Revenue Service by filing IRS Form SS-4. The TIN serves to keep the trust assets separate from those of the settlor and identifies the trust in bank accounts and tax returns. Do not use your own social security number or the disabled beneficiary's social security number. The Trust must have its own TIN.3. Funding the Trust. The ownership of one or more assets must be transferred to the trustee for the trust to be in effect. The bank or brokerage account or the asset itself, such as shares of stock, should be titled in the name of the trust, as follows: "[Name of trustee], Trustee of The [Name of disabled beneficiary] Special Needs Trust dated [month] [day] [year]." (Some banks may want to use a slightly different name.)To transfer funds from checking, savings, and brokerage accounts, the TIN should be provided. A bank or brokerage firm may request a copy of the signed trust instrument for examination by the firm's legal department. We generally do not provide a copy of the entire agreement. A copy of the signature page and the trustee powers will serve to demonstrate that the trust has been properly executed and the trustee has the necessary power to borrow money, buy and sell stocks, bonds, and options, trade on margin, and conduct other trust business. A certification of trust prepared in accordance with Ohio law may also sometimes be used in lieu of the entire trust agreement.To transfer real estate into the trust, a deed must be executed and recorded granting the property to the trust. We can prepare the deed for the property for signature by [name of disabled beneficiary / name of guardian]. Upon obtaining the necessary signatures, we will record the deed at the county Recorder of Deeds office. You should contact the homeowner's insurance company to notify them of the title change.4. Administration of the Trust. (a) Taxation of Trust Income. File IRS Form 1041 and Ohio IT 1041 to report the income for any year in which the trust has taxable income. These forms are due on April 15 of the year following the receipt of the taxable income. We strongly recommend retaining an accountant for the preparation of tax returns.(b) Distributions from the Trust. The Trust was created to provide [name of disabled beneficiary] with supplemental means of support in addition to, not as replacement of, [name of disabled beneficiary]'s government benefits. Accordingly, the types of distributions that can be made to the disabled beneficiary are limited. In general, distributions should not be made for basic support, which includes (1) housing (e.g., mortgage, real property taxes, rent, etc.); (2) utilities (e.g., gas, electricity, water, sewer, waste service, etc.); (3) food; (4) clothing; and (5) medical treatment for which public or Medicaid funds are available. The government benefits are meant to cover these expenses and any payment of them using the Trust's funds could result in the loss of benefits. All distributions from the Trust are at the discretion of the trustee. Here are some examples of items for which distributions are permissible:(i) phone, cable, and internet service(ii) entertainment (e.g., concerts, museums, theater, movies, tickets to sports events, subscriptions)(iii) furniture(iv) computer hardware and software(v) education expenses unrelated to room and board (i.e., tuition, books, computers, supplies)(vi) medical equipment not covered by any other benefit(vii) travel(viii) nonfood grocery items (e.g., cleaning supplies, personal hygiene products, tissues)(ix) eyeglasses –and–(x) automobile expensesCash or cash equivalents should not be distributed directly to the beneficiary, even if they are reimbursements or prepayments for acceptable expenditures. Instead, payments should be made directly to third parties. Distributions also should not be made to or for the benefit of anyone other than the beneficiary.If you have any questions about permissible distributions, please do not hesitate to contact me.(c) Recordkeeping. Please maintain detailed records of the trust assets, income, and expenditures, including the date, amount, payee, and purpose of each transaction. You may be required to provide a comprehensive accounting of the Trust to the Ohio Department of Medicaid upon termination of the Trust.(d) Yearly Statement of Claims. Under Ohio law, the Trust must include a provision for reimbursement to the Ohio Department of Medicaid (ODM) upon the death of the disabled beneficiary. This reimbursement must equal the total amount of Medicaid benefits paid on behalf of the trust beneficiary. As trustee, you will receive an annual Statement of Claims (SOC) from the ODM, which will detail the current amount owed. The SOC will include a running total of all medical expenses covered by Medicaid for [name of disabled beneficiary] since the execution of the Trust.(e) Reimbursement to the ODM. If the trust is terminated or [name of disabled beneficiary] passes away, you, as trustee, must notify the ODM as soon as possible. You can send the notification to ODM, Bureau of Third Party Liability, 50 W. Town Street, Suite 400, Columbus, OH 43215. The ODM will then provide a final comprehensive Statement of Claims (SOC) to you, detailing the total reimbursement amount owed to the ODM. If the ODM will not be fully reimbursed from the trust, a final accounting of the trust funds should be included with the payment.5. Termination of the Trust. The trust will terminate if any of the following events occur:(a) There are no more assets in the trust.(b) The disabled beneficiary dies. Upon the beneficiary's death, any remaining trust assets shall first be used to reimburse the Ohio Department of Medicaid (or any other state agency providing medical assistance) for the total amount of medical assistance paid on behalf of the beneficiary under the Medicaid program. After the satisfaction of any such claims, the remaining assets shall be distributed to the beneficiary's descendants or other contingent beneficiaries as specified in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust.6. Trustee Powers. A detailed list of the trustee's powers can be found in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust. Please make sure you understand them. I am happy to answer any questions you may have about them.I hope that this letter has answered your immediate questions. If you would like further explanation of any aspect of funding or administering the trust, please do not hesitate to contact me.
Sincerely,____________________[Name of attorney]End of Document

Letter to Client 
[Month Day, Year][name of client 1] [OPTIONAL: and [name of client 2]][address]RE: Funding of Revocable TrustDear [first name of client 1] [OPTIONAL: and [first name of client 2]]:FUNDING YOUR REVOCABLE TRUSTNow that you, as Settlor(s), have established your Revocable Trust, it must be funded by transferring ownership of some or all of your assets to the Trust. If you own any assets jointly and undividedly with one or more persons and wish to transfer those assets into your Revocable Trust, all of the joint title owners will have to join in the conveyance.This memorandum provides a general description of the steps necessary to transfer many kinds of assets to your Revocable Trusts. Of course, the specific steps to accomplish this transfer will depend on the nature of the asset involved. If you would like assistance with any of these transfers, please contact my office. I can assist you in the asset transfer process, including the preparation of deeds and obtaining and filing necessary documentation.Please examine your assets to determine which assets to transfer into your Revocable Trust. The types of assets that may be transferred include stocks, bonds, real property located in any state or country, mineral and royalty interests, tangible personal property, bank accounts, brokerage accounts, certificates of deposit, life insurance policies, corporate or partnership interests, outstanding notes, and any other type of ownership interests you may hold. Assets that cannot be transferred to the trust during your lifetimes include IRAs and some types of annuities.In general, to transfer assets to your Trusts, you will need to change the title for each asset from your names individually or jointly to the Revocable Trust, as follows:[name of client 1] and [name of client 2] as TRUSTEES of the [name of Revocable Living Trust], dated [month] [day], [year]One of the major goals accomplished by a Revocable Trust as the main instrument in your estate plan is to avoid probate of the trust assets at the time of your deaths. In order to avoid probate, it is critically important that assets be owned by the serving Trustee of the Revocable Trust and not by you individually and/or jointly, as outlined above. Although your pour-over Will provides that assets held in your individual name at your death will be added to the trust assets and distributed as provided in your Trust Agreement, those assets will be subject to probate before they are added to the trust property. To avoid that result, you may wish retitle all assets in the name of your Revocable Trust as outlined above.You should carefully and continually review the assets held in your own names (both assets that you now own and any that you acquire later) to be certain that this is consistent with your estate planning goals. I will be glad to discuss the advisability of retaining ownership of various assets in your name alone, holding assets in joint names with another person, or transferring assets to the Trustee of your Revocable Trust. Generally speaking, unless there are compelling reasons to do otherwise, I do not recommend that your personal checking or small savings accounts, or tangible personal property (jewelry, automobiles, etc.) be transferred to the Trust. Please feel free to call me to discuss whether my general recommendation applies to your particular situation.On the following pages, I offer some general guidance on transferring specific types of assets to your Revocable Trust. These comments are general in nature, and if you require specific guidance, please contact my office.Accounts or Certificates Issued by a Bank or Other Savings Institution. The name on the account or certificate must be changed to reflect its ownership by the Trustee, and a new passbook or certificate must be issued in the name of the Trustee. Be careful to confirm with the financial institution before transferring a savings certificate that there will be no penalty for early withdrawal.Brokerage Accounts. If you own stocks, bonds, or other securities through a brokerage account, the brokerage firm's name and records must be changed to indicate that the Trustee owns the account and you do not own it individually. This also applies if the certificates for those assets are not issued in your name but are held instead in a street name or in the brokerage firm's name.Corporate Stocks (Issued by Publicly or Privately Held Corporations) or Mutual Fund Shares. If certificates are issued in your name, both individual or jointly, new certificates must be issued to reflect the Trustee's ownership of the stock or shares. You may be able to combine all certificates representing shares in one corporation into one new certificate, but you may wish to consider requesting a series of new certificates, one corresponding to each old certificate, in order to trace your income tax basis if any shares are sold by the Trustee during your lifetimes.Registered Bonds or Debentures (Issued by Publicly or Privately Held Corporations, the U.S. Government, an Agency, any State, or Subdivision thereof). These securities must also be registered in the name of the Trustee and new bonds or debentures reissued. As with stock certificates discussed above, if bonds or debentures are held in a brokerage account, title to the account must be changed.Unregistered or Bearer Bonds or Debentures. These securities, typically issued by the United States government, an agency, a state, or a municipality, generally cannot be registered in the name of the Trustee, so that there must be some other evidence that these securities have been transferred. This can be accomplished by executing and delivering to the Trustee an Assignment to Revocable Trust, listing the bearer securities being transferred, which will be retained by the Trustee with the permanent records of the trust. I can prepare for you any documents necessary to accomplish the transfer. It would be helpful to keep bearer securities in a safe deposit box in the name of the Trustee with a duplicate copy of the transfer document attached.Tangible Investment Assets (Such as Gold Bullion, Silver Coins, Art Objects). Because there is often no proof of registration or ownership of these assets, their transfer to your Revocable Trust should be handled in a manner similar to that described for unregistered securities. Any new investments of this type should be purchased directly in the name of the Trustee with the confirmation or other purchase slip retained with the instrument or investment to prove the Trustee's ownership.Partnership Interests (Whether in a General Partnership or Limited Partnership). In order to register these partnership interests in the Trustee's name, a new certificate of partnership interest or an amendment to the partnership agreement may need to be executed. There may be restrictions against transfer in the partnership agreement, so it should be reviewed before the transfer is attempted.Interests in Real Property (Personal Residence, Investment Real Estate, and Mineral and Royalty Interests). Legal title must be transferred to the Trustee by means of an executed, notarized, and recorded deed, usually a Special Warranty Deed. Be careful to determine whether any existing mortgage or deed of trust secured by the transferred real estate will be affected by the proposed transfer and whether the proposed transfer will trigger any "due on sale" clause in the mortgage or deed of trust. It is important to comply carefully with the requirements of the law of the state where the property is located. You may wish to consult with a title agent to ensure that the property interest is eligible for transfer.Beneficiary-Designated Assets, such as Life Insurance Policies, Annuities, and Retirement Plan Benefits. The death benefits of these assets can be made payable to the trustee, if desired, for distribution under the terms of the Trust. However, please consult with me before taking this step, because these transfers may involve unexpected complications. Life insurance policies generally pass outside of probate, just as revocable trusts do. Thus, in most cases life insurance policies are not transferred to revocable trusts. However, if there is a need to grant the trustee of your Revocable Trust control over the policy distributions, or if you fear you may become disabled and unable to administer your life insurance policy, you may wish to transfer ownership of the policy to the trustee of your Revocable Trust. IRAs and 401Ks should never be transferred to a Revocable Trust during the Settlor's lifetime. You may, however, wish to consult with me about the feasibility of establishing a trust to hold retirement assets inherited by your beneficiaries. Some annuities do not permit transfers, and others have negative tax consequences if transferred to a revocable trust. I would be happy to review your annuity contract and, if necessary, consult with the insurance company or plan trustee to determine whether your annuity is transferrable. Change-of-beneficiary forms from the insurance company or the administrator of the retirement plan must be completed and recorded with the insurer or the plan Trustee to name the Trustee of your Revocable Trust as the beneficiary of any benefits. Some annuities do not permit transfers, and others have negative tax consequences if put into the Revocable Trust, so caution is advised.Safe Deposit Box. Many institutions allow a Revocable Trust to maintain a safe deposit box. This is useful in avoiding the need to obtain a court order or institute a probate proceeding simply to open the safe deposit box where no alternate individual is named with access to the box.Leases and Promissory Notes. Where a rental property is being transferred into the Revocable Trust, you should inform your tenants that the trust is now the nominal owner of the property and that future lease payments should be made to the trust. It also may be beneficial to inform tenants that the terms of their existing lease will not change, but any renewal or new lease should reflect that the landlord is the Revocable Trust. There is no need to show the tenants any portion of the Trust Agreement. Similarly, promissory notes may be assigned to the Revocable Trust, in which case the payor should be informed that the trust holds the note, that the terms of the note have not changed, and that the next payment should be made to the Revocable Trust as payee. Any liens securing notes transferred to the Revocable Trust should also be assigned to the trust and filed in the appropriate county or municipality. As with the lease, there is no need to show the payor any portion of the Trust Agreement.Firearms. While it is not illegal for your Revocable Trust to own firearms, it is ill-advised to transfer into or hold firearms in the trust. In addition to it imposing significant risk and liability to the Trustee, most firearms are highly regulated and, under Federal law, some individuals are considered prohibited persons concerning firearm ownership. Firearm laws are complex, and failure to abide by them can result in fines and imprisonment. For the purposes of holding and transferring firearms there are special purpose "gun trusts".Once an asset has been transferred to the Trustee of your Revocable Trust, all transactions regarding that asset must be handled by the Trustee, rather than by you individually and/or jointly (even if you are the initial Trustees of the Revocable Trust). For example, after corporate stock has been transferred to the Trustee, it is the Trustee who has the power to sell, mortgage, or assign those shares of stock or to vote them at a shareholders' meeting. Any document evidencing the transfer of assets must be signed by the Trustee.Additional assets may be transferred to your Revocable Trust either by registering them in the name of the Trustee, by delivering them to the Trustee with appropriate documents to re-register the assets in the name of the Trustee, or with other transfer documents if the asset is of the nonregistered type. Withdrawals of property from your Revocable Trust must comply with the provisions of the Trust Agreement. I can prepare documents for you to accomplish such withdrawal. The Trust Agreement can be amended or revoked in its entirety, but any amendment or revocation must comply with the procedural requirements of the Trust Agreement.Federal income tax returns for a Revocable Trust are not required. If the Settlors are also the Trustee or a co-Trustee, a federal tax identification number for the trust is also not necessary, and all income is reported using the Settlors' social security numbers (which becomes the Revocable Trust's taxpayer identification number). If the Settlors are not Trustees, the Settlors' social security numbers can still be used, but the Trustee must meet certain other requirements in that case. After the Settlors' death, a federal tax identification number must be obtained for the Trust.Please call me if you have any questions about the transfer of property to your trust or about the operation of the trust in the future. This memorandum is for your guidance only and does not encompass all possible situations.
Sincerely yours,____________________ [name of attorney]End of Document

Estate Plan for Individual with Spouse or Partner Resource Kit (FL)
Go to: Initial Client Meeting   |   Wills   |   Trusts   |   Disability Planning   |   Powers of AttorneyMaintainedThis resource kit provides guidance on creating an estate plan for an individual with a spouse or partner residing in Florida. An estate plan is defined as an arrangement providing for the use, management, investment, conservation, and transfer of an individual's property during their lifetime or after death. The documents utilized by counsel in creating an estate plan will vary depending on the client's circumstances, family needs, estate size, and wishes, among other things. For example, there may be reasons for a client to create a trust on behalf of their beneficiaries rather than gift assets outright to them, or vice versa. In addition to wills and trusts, there may be a need for medical powers of attorney, financial powers of attorney, or various other estate planning tools. This resource kit includes Practical Guidance materials on these potential options, including detailed practice notes, templates, and checklists.Initial Client MeetingMost estate planning matters begin with information gathering at or immediately before the initial client meeting. The details shared by the client at the beginning of the matter help to determine the appropriate and best estate planning tools for the client. It is crucial for counsel to ascertain a client's objectives as well as estate information, and it is good practice for this information to be sought out prior to the initial client meeting by way of an estate planning questionnaire. An estate planning questionnaire will inquire into the client's assets; personal information about things like their marriage, children, citizenship, etc.; and their desired fiduciaries.The following Practical Guidance resources will guide you through the early stages of crafting an estate plan for your client:Go to table1WillsOnce the client's estate planning objectives are ascertained and the necessary information is gathered, the attorney must consider the proper tools to carry out those objectives. In many instances, more than one estate planning tool can be used to achieve a desired objective. A will is the most basic tool in the estate planner's kit. A will enables the client to designate how their assets should be distributed after death and who should oversee that process. A will may also address certain post-death concerns, such as caring for a minor child. You must remember that this tool works only for assets held in the client's name alone and does not work for assets for which there are beneficiary designations, such as life insurance, or for jointly owned property with a right of survivorship.The following Practical Guidance resources will guide you through drafting a will or a codicil for your client:Go to table2TrustsA trust is a legal arrangement pursuant to which a settlor or grantor transfers property to a trustee to administer on behalf of one or more beneficiaries in accordance with the terms of the governing instrument. The trustee is the legal owner of the trust assets and is tasked with administering them but does so only on behalf of the beneficiaries. Although trusts can be classified according to a number of criteria, the most important to note are inter vivos trusts or living trusts, which go into effect during the grantor's lifetime and can be either revocable or irrevocable, and testamentary trusts, which go into effect after the grantor dies. There are several reasons why a client may want to include a trust in their estate plan (e.g., avoid probate, hold out of state property, plan for future incapacity, seek out tax benefits, and/or keep asset information private).The following Practical Guidance resources will guide you through drafting or amending a trust for your client:Go to table3Disability PlanningA comprehensive estate plan will likely include provisions outlining what should take place in the event of a client's disability. A health care surrogate designation can be used to authorize a health care agent to make medical or other health care decisions on an individual's behalf. A living will is an advance health care directive that details the medical measures a person does or does not want taken in a variety of potential circumstances. Both instruments serve to ensure an individual's health care wishes are followed if they cannot enforce those decisions due to a disability or other circumstance. In addition, certain clients may benefit from guidance concerning elder law planning.The following Practical Guidance resources will provide more information and guide you through this aspect of a client's estate plan:Go to table4Powers of AttorneyPowers of attorney are often included as part of a client's estate plan. A power of attorney is the legal instrument by which an individual (the principal) authorizes another individual (the attorney-in-fact or agent) to make certain business, financial, and personal decisions on their behalf.The following Practical Guidance resources will provide more information on powers of attorney in Florida:Go to table5Current as of: 05/20/2025
