Letter to Financial Institution 
[name of client(s)][address line 1][address line 2][Month Day, 20__][name of financial institution][financial institution address line 1][financial institution address line 2]Via [type of mail service]Re: Transfer to Revocable TrustAccount Number(s) [account number(s)]To Whom It May Concern:[I/we] wish to change the title of the following accounts to [my/our] revocable trust, The [name of revocable trust] dated [Month Day, 20__]:1. [type of account], account number [account number]Please transfer title of the above listed accounts into the following ownership:[name of trustee], as TRUSTEE of [name of revocable trust] dated [Month Day, 20__].Supporting Document: Enclosed please find a copy of the Certification of Trust for the [name of revocable trust], which documents the establishment of this Trust and sets out the powers for the handling of assets by the Trustee. Please continue to use the Social Security Number currently associated with the account(s) being transferred as the Tax Identification Number for the account. As per IRS Regulation 1.671-4(b), no separate Tax Identification Number is required for this type of trust.If you have any questions regarding this transfer, please contact [me/us] using the information listed below. Thank you for your assistance and prompt attention to this matter.Sincerely,[name of client][client address line 1][client address line 2][client phone number][client email address]End of Document

Letter to Client 
Table of Contents
Dear [name of client]:I am writing regarding the [name of beneficiary] Supplemental Needs Trust Agreement dated [month] [day], [year], which we have prepared for you as [settlor of the trust/trustee of the trust/both settlor and trustee of the trust].The purpose of this letter is to (1) describe the process of transferring assets into the trust, and (2) address what you, as [settlor/trustee/both settlor and trustee] of the trust, need to know and think about while administering the trust. Therefore, I advise you to keep this letter for future reference. To accomplish the long-term goals for which the trust was created, the settlor and trustee must adhere to the terms of the trust agreement and the tax laws relating to trusts. If you have any questions about the tax laws relating to this trust, please do not hesitate to ask me or a tax professional.The trust describes the responsibilities and the powers of the trustee(s). Since all trust documents (also called trust instruments) do not contain the same powers, the trustee must pay special attention to the language in the trust to be certain of the trustee's authority and options.This trust is a third-party supplemental needs trust. It is designed so that the family and friends of [name of beneficiary], the beneficiary of the trust, can make gifts to benefit [name of beneficiary] while preserving the right to receive government benefits. The gifts made to the trust can take many forms: cash, bonds, shares of stock, real property, or even personal property. Under no circumstances should any property or assets belonging to the beneficiary be transferred into the trust. If this is done, it could jeopardize the beneficiary's eligibility for government benefits. Also, the beneficiary has no right to demand or withdraw any assets or property from the trust.Here are some features of trust management with which you should familiarize yourself:Irrevocability of Trust. The trust is an irrevocable trust. That means it is fixed and cannot be amended or terminated, except under very limited circumstances. Also, gifts made to the trust cannot be returned. Please call me if you need to make any changes to the trust.Federal Tax Identification Number. This trust was drafted to qualify as a grantor trust. A grantor trust is a trust over which the grantor or other owner retains the power to control or direct the trust's income or assets. If the trust is a grantor trust, the trustee has the choice of reporting the annual income for federal tax purposes on either IRS Form 1041 or on the income tax return of the grantor. A grantor trust does not need its own TIN.Funding the Trust. The ownership of one or more assets must be transferred to the trustee for the trust to be funded and in effect. The bank or brokerage account or the asset itself, such as shares of stock, should be titled in the name of the trust, as follows: "[name of trustee], Trustee of The [name of beneficiary] Supplemental Needs Trust dated [month] [day], [year]." (Your bank may want to use a slightly different name.) If the trust is not a grantor trust, always use the trust's TIN as the identification number for bank accounts.Financial institutions often require a copy of the signed trust agreement to verify that the trust is in effect. Providing a copy of the complete trust agreement is generally unnecessary. Typically, a copy of the Certification of Trust or the first page, the executed signature pages, and the page delineating trustee powers are sufficient to demonstrate that the trust has been properly executed and the trustee has the necessary power to borrow money, buy and sell stocks, bonds, and options, trade on margin, and conduct other trust business. To transfer real estate into the trust, a deed must be executed and recorded granting the property to the trust. Gift Tax Return. If any gift to the trust exceeds $18,000.00 in value, the donor should be instructed to complete a gift tax return (IRS Form 709) by April 15 of the following year. Please consult me concerning allocating some or all of your generation-skipping tax exemption to this trust.Taxation of Trust Income. The trustee is required to file IRS Form 1041 and Connecticut Form CT-1041 to report the income for any year in which the trust has taxable income. These forms are due on April 15 of the year following the taxable year. Although tax software is widely available for this purpose, we strongly recommend having these forms prepared by an accountant because of their complexity. Distributions from the Trust. The types of distributions that can be made to the disabled beneficiary are limited to those which will not jeopardize the benefits received from any county, state, federal, or other government agency. In general, distributions should not be made for basic support (e.g., housing, food, clothing, and medical treatment for which public or Medicaid funds are available). Here are some examples of permissible distributions: automobile, computer equipment, subscriptions, travel, furniture, education (tuition, books, supplies), health insurance, life insurance, sports equipment, tickets to events. Cash or cash equivalents should not be distributed directly to the beneficiary. If you have any questions about permissible distributions, please do not hesitate to contact me. Termination of the Trust. The trust will terminate if any of the following events occur:• There are no more assets in the trust.• The disabled beneficiary dies, and the assets of the trust are distributed to the beneficiary's descendants or to the other contingent beneficiaries named in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust.• The beneficiary has become ineligible for public benefits, per Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust.Please inform me if any of these events take place. At that time, it may be necessary to draw up a formal trust dissolution document.Trustee Powers. A detailed list of the trustee's powers can be found in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust. Please read them and make sure you understand them. I will be happy to answer any questions you may have about them.Record Keeping. It is important that the trustee keep records of trust property separate from property that may not be in the trust. The settlor and the trustee will receive monthly and other account statements in the name of the trust.
I hope this letter answered your immediate questions. If you would like further explanation of any aspect of administering the trust, please do not hesitate to contact me.Sincerely,____________________[name of attorney]End of Document

Requirements and Restrictions on Trust Purposes and Administration (FL)
Go to: Formal Requirements   |   Restrictions on Trust Purposes   |   Trustees and Trust AdministrationMaintainedby Jonathan E. Gopman, Nelson MullinsThis practice note discusses the requirements for creating a valid trust in Florida, including intent, identifiable property, ascertainable beneficiaries and proper execution. It also discusses restrictions on trust purposes, such as illegality and provisions in contravention of public policy. Finally, the note addresses the appointment and succession of trustees and the duties, responsibilities, and liability of trustees.For a full listing of key content related to estate plans for married or partnered people in Florida, see Estate Plan for Individual with Spouse or Partner Resource Kit (FL).For a full listing of key content related to estate plans for individual people in Florida, see Estate Plan for Single Individual Resource Kit (FL).For further discussion of trusts, see Characteristics and Uses of Trusts (FL) and Revocation, Amendment, and Termination of Trusts (FL).Formal RequirementsIntentIt is axiomatic that a settlor cannot create an express trust without the intent to do so. There is a requirement for a trust to be in writing (as discussed below), Thus, it is nearly impossible to conceive of a fact pattern where a settlor is alleged to have created an express trust by implication. Issues of intent therefore generally center on whether the settlor lacked capacity to enter into a trust, whether the creation of the trust was induced by fraud or undue influence, or whether the trust was created by mistake. See Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.03[1].The capacity required of the settlor of a trust is the same as the capacity required to make a will. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0601. If the settlor lacks capacity to convey property, then no trust arises.  Fraud, duress, undue influence, and mistake can also cause a trust to be void. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0406. See Florida Probate Code Manual § 2.05.In Florida, a trust does not have to be in writing; however, the creation of an oral trust and its terms may be established only by clear and convincing evidence. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0407. See also 55A Fla Jur Trusts § 262.Identifiable PropertyFor a valid trust to exist at common law it must hold assets (i.e., there must be a trust res or property delivered to the trustee). However, as discussed in the Reasons for Creating a Trust, unfunded revocable trusts are common. How are these concepts reconciled? Simply put, an unfunded revocable or irrevocable trust is not a valid trust. It only becomes a valid trust upon funding. Could it be problematic to have a trust that is not yet.valid? There is some concern that a trust that is not yet valid could not be effectively named as a beneficiary under a pour-over will. However, Fla. Stat. § 736.0401(1) makes it clear that if a trust instrument is validly executed, the trust may be a beneficiary under a will. There is no pre-death funding requirement for transfers of property by will in the statute. Nevertheless, as a matter of caution it is common practice to recite in the schedule of trust assets some nominal amount of money (e.g., $10) to satisfy the requirement for a res. To satisfy the delivery requirement a $10 bill is sometimes affixed to the schedule. However, affixing a $10 bill to the schedule of a trust can create problems for institutional trustees who may be prohibited under anti-money laundering policies and procedures from accepting cash transfers. In practice, the requirement of a  is unlikely to be an issue, but if a contest is anticipated, an estate planner may want to advise a settlor to fund the trust with more than a nominal sum promptly after its creation.Ascertainable BeneficiariesAnother common law rule is that a trust must have ascertainable beneficiaries to be valid. This does not mean that a trust must have current beneficiaries. A trust is valid if there are no current beneficiaries for a period and income must be accumulated for that period. However, there must be some party in a position to enforce the trust. The party enforcing the trust need not be an individual. For instance, charities or other trusts, or in theory, other legal entities, can be beneficiaries. See Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.03[2]. Additionally, animals that were living during a settlor's lifetime can be the sole current beneficiaries of trusts. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0408. See also Florida Probate Code Manual § 14.085.In contrast, a trust instrument is not required to specify a trustee. A trustee can always be appointed similar to a vacancy in the office of trustee being filled by a court proceeding.Execution Requirements (If Testamentary in Nature, etc.)Fla. Stat. § 736.0403(2)(b) states that "[t]he testamentary aspects of a revocable trust, executed by a settlor who is a domiciliary of this state at the time of execution, are invalid unless the trust instrument is executed by the settlor with the formalities required for the execution of a will in this state." The term testamentary aspects means "those provisions of the trust that dispose of the trust property on or after the death of the settlor other than to the settlor's estate." Id.; Robinson v. Robinson (In re Estate of Robinson), 720 So. 2d. 540, 541-542 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 4th Dist. 1998). This statute generally applies to trusts drafted in other states. It can be a surprise clients who move from another state to Florida because it is an exception to the general rule that a trust (and generally other legal documents) is valid if it was executed in conformity with the law of the jurisdiction in which, at its creation, the settlor was domiciled. See, e.g., Fla. Stat. § 736.0403(1). See also Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.04.Restrictions on Trust PurposesGenerally, a trust may be created for any purpose that is not illegal. Although historically, many trusts in Florida have successfully withstood trust contests, there are restrictions on the purpose for which a trust may be created.• Illegality. Florida trusts may be created only to the extent that the purposes of the trust are "lawful, not contrary to public policy, and possible to achieve." Fla. Stat. § 736.0105(2)(c); Fla. Stat. § 736.0404. Presumably, for example, a trust could not be used for the payment of bribes. A trust may also fail if it was settled to avoid the settlor's creditors. See e.g., Fla. Stat. § 736.0505(1); and Fla. Stat. §§ 726.105 and 726.106.• Provisions Contrary to Public Policy. While it is rare to encounter a purpose issue involving an illegality, it is not uncommon to encounter provisions that are contrary to public policy. The comment to the Uniform Trust Code provides generally that purposes that violate public policy include those that tend to encourage criminal or tortious conduct, interfere with freedom to marry or encourage divorce, limit religious freedom, or which are frivolous or capricious. See Comment to § 404, Unif. Tr. Code (Apr. 10, 2020 at p. 59), available at https://www.uniformlaws.org/HigherLogic/System/DownloadDocumentFile.ashx?DocumentFileKey=73cfb939-8b5b-53f6-bc09-6323ebe26f3d&forceDialog=0 (last visited March 17, 2022). Another example of incurring a public policy issue in Florida may include a self-settled asset protection trust, as Florida law generally does not permit such trusts. Fla. Stat. § 736.0505(1).Trustees and Trust AdministrationThe selection of trustees and the administration of the trust are critical components of manifesting the intent of the settlor. Bifurcation of property ownership is the defining characteristic of a trust and as such, the trustee, as the individual holding title to the assets of the trust, maintains an active role in its administration.TrusteesGenerally, any individual, or a corporate trustee such as a bank or trust company, may serve as trustee.AppointmentThe selection of a trustee depends on a number of factors, including:• The settlor's preference• The time commitment that will be required of a prospective trustee• Conflicts that may exist between a potential trustee and one or more beneficiaries of the trust• The size, complexity, and potential risk of the assets of the trustWhile the settlor may desire an independent trustee (e.g., a corporate trustee), the prospective trustee may be reluctant to serve, for example, where the trust assets consist of real estate holdings that have not been evaluated for potential risks (e.g., environmental hazards) and such an undertaking would be cost prohibitive. More often, the size of the trust estate may not justify the fee structure of an institutional trustee. If the trust instrument nominates as trustee a bank that no longer exists, no longer accepts trust business, or refuses to administer the particular trust, and no other mechanism of filling the vacancy in the office of trustee is provided, the only solution may be to seek court appointment of a trustee. To avoid this situation the trust instrument should appoint a successor trustee or provide a provision for the last trustee, beneficiaries, or another third party to appoint a new trustee.Notably, designating a trustee does not compel that individual or entity to serve. The trustee must voluntarily qualify (i.e., formally accept appointment) before commencing to serve. The initial trustees of an inter vivos trust qualify by signing the trust instrument.  Successor trustees of an inter vivos trust accept by signing the instrument under which they are appointed, or they sign a separate instrument drafted for that specific purpose (i.e., an acceptance of trust). In all cases, proper documentation is essential to preclude any claims that a trustee is acting without due authority. Best practices further suggest preparing documentation for the acceptance of trusteeship under testamentary trusts, including any sub-trusts that may come into existence under the trust instrument after the death of the settlor. See Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.05.SuccessionIf a trust instrument designates a successor trustee or provides for a process of designating a successor trustee, there is generally no problem. However, even where a successor is not designated in the trust instrument, Florida law contains a flexible mechanism for the appointment of successor trustees to permit the beneficiaries to avoid court proceedings in many cases where a successor trustee is necessary. See Fla. Stat. §§ 736.0704(3)-(4).Regardless, when drafting a Florida trust, it is recommended that estate planners incorporate multiple layers of trustee succession provisions. To be thorough the practitioner may:• Empower the grantor to designate successors• Authorize the grantor's spouse to designate successors• Nominate a series of successor trustees, in order of priority listed, to serve as trustee• Provide that the last acting trustee may appoint a further successor• Provide that a majority of the adult beneficiaries of the trust may fill any vacancy –and–• Identify a corporate trusteeA practitioner may also nominate a trust protector to fill a vacancy. While estate planners do not typically provide for all these options, some subset of these options is advisable.The unrestricted power of a grantor or beneficiary to remove and replace trustees presents a trap for the unwary as such a power may present tax complications. See Rev. Rul. 95-58, 1995-2 C.B. 191. However, the mere power to designate successors should not be problematic. If the trust should not be included in the grantor's estate for estate tax purposes, the attorney will generally provide in the trust instrument that the grantor cannot, under any circumstances, become a trustee.Trust AdministrationEffective administration of a trust requires knowledge and understanding of the trustee's fiduciary and other duties associated with administering the trust and the responsibilities and liabilities inherent in the trustee's position.Duties of a TrusteeAs noted in the Characteristics and Uses of Trusts (FL) and Requirements and Restrictions on Trust Purposes and Administration (FL) and Revocation, Amendment, and Termination of Trusts (FL) section above, one of the fundamental characteristics of a trust is the trustee's fiduciary duty to the beneficiaries. Under a fiduciary duty a trustee must act in the best interests of the beneficiaries, which requires a certain degree of selflessness. Perhaps the most famous statement regarding fiduciary duty in American jurisprudence is set forth in a New York Court of Appeals case, Meinhard v. Salmon, 249 N.Y. 458 (1928), in which Judge Cardozo stated: "A trustee is held to something stricter than the morals of the market place. Not honesty alone, but the punctilio of an honor the most sensitive, is then the standard of behavior." See Meinhard, 249 N.Y. at 464.Furthermore, as the Florida Supreme Court declared:Stripped of all embellishing verbiage it may be confidently asserted that every instance in which a confidential or fiduciary relation in fact is shown to exist will be interpreted as such. The relation and duties involved need not be legal, they may be moral, social, domestic or personal. If a relation of trust and confidence exists between the parties, that is to say, where confidence is reposed by one party and a trust accepted by the other, or where confidence has been acquired and abused, that is sufficient as a predicate for relief. The origin of the confidence is immaterial.Quinn v. Phillips, 93 Fla. 805, 811 (1927) (emphasis added).The broad concept of a trustee's fiduciary duty has been divided into various individual duties, which will be discussed in more detail below. First, however, it is important to highlight one point that is often overlooked in discussions about fiduciary duties. This point is that not all fiduciaries are equal. For example, an attorney-in-fact under a power of attorney is a fiduciary, however, an attorney-in-fact has no affirmative obligation to act on behalf of the principal, whereas the fiduciary who has accepted the office of trustee has agreed to such a commitment. The fiduciary duties of attorneys-in-fact originate from the law of agency, not the law of trusts, and though this has not been written about extensively, less is expected of agents than of trustees. In particular, though this issue occurs more often in other contexts than in estate planning, breaches of fiduciary duty in the agency context can generally be excused if such breaches are properly disclosed, however, in the context of a trust, disclosure alone will not suffice. Rather, informed written consent is required.Duty of LoyaltyOf the various individual duties owed by trustees, the most important is the duty of loyalty. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0802. The trustee is obligated to act with undivided loyalty to the beneficiaries. The trust must be administered solely in the interests of the beneficiaries, and not in the interests of the trustee. Fla. Stat. § 736.0802(1). See Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.07. However, the trustee is entitled to be paid reasonable compensation. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0802(7)(b). See also Administration of Trusts in Florida § 13.2.A trustee is typically prohibited from engaging in self-dealing (i.e., transactions between the trustee and the trust) for the obvious reason that the trustee cannot be relied upon to seek the best result for the trust and its beneficiaries when the trustee is on the other side of the transaction. Self-dealing is an issue under conflicts of interest. A trustee is honor-bound to avoid a conflict of interest. If, for example, a trust owns thirty percent (30%) of the stock in a company, and the trustee of that trust individually owns 30% of the stock, the mere potential for a biased vote creates a conflict of interest. Where the trustee is permitted to vote the stock held in the trust, the trustee may not vote those shares in a manner that will benefit the trustee personally unless such vote is also in the best interests of the trust and its beneficiaries.Interestingly, the evolution of modern financial institutions has led to a decreasing application of the prohibition on self-dealing and conflicts of interest. For example, a corporate trustee may want to invest the assets of the trust in mutual funds of an affiliate of the trustee. Under traditional trust law, this would be considered self-dealing, and as such, prohibited. Whether it is because of a recognition that it could well be in the best interests of the trust to permit such investments or lobbying from the financial services industry, such investments are now specifically authorized by statute. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0802(5)(a). However, unless the trust agreement provides otherwise, the trustee must choose between earning commissions on such investments or its affiliate earning its standard fees. The statute does not condone double-dipping of fees. Accordingly, many corporate fiduciaries will insist on inclusion of language in the trust agreement overriding the proscription against double-dipping of fees and authorizing a range of transactions that would otherwise constitute self-dealing transactions. It is asserted that this is done because the settlor is selecting the trustee at least in part because of the range of investments that will be made available to the trust. When drafting a trust that will name a corporate trustee, the estate planner should obtain from the trustee its preferred language early on in the drafting process to negotiate the self-dealing provisions as needed and ultimately incorporate those provisions into the trust document.Duty of CareThe next most basic individual duty a trustee owes is the duty of care, meaning the responsibility to administer the trust with the care and skill of an ordinary prudent person. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0804. If the fiduciary has particular expertise in an area, a higher standard will generally apply. See Fla. Stat. § 518.11(1)(a) and Fla. Stat. § 736.0806. For example, a trustee who is an accountant will be expected to possess knowledge of the tax law better than a trustee who is not a tax professional. Furthermore, a corporate trustee will be expected to keep impeccable records whereas an individual trustee might be excused for minor lapses in record keeping. There are two important points to consider in this context. First, prudence does not mean perfection. If a trustee makes prudent investments that do not produce a quality return, the trustee has not breached its duty of care even though the trust may have decreased in value. Second, prudence is process-driven rather than a results-driven. If the decision-making process is procedurally sound, the trustee has fulfilled the duty of care regardless of the result. Still, it may be challenging to establish a sound process. Therefore, the attorney should encourage trustee clients to document their decision-making as thoroughly as possible. Detailed minutes of trustee meetings can save the trustee from liability. Non-trust lawyers sometimes have a bias against maintaining detailed minutes because they feel that any more detail than absolutely necessary gives potential litigants fuel for lawsuits. Whether or not that is true in other contexts, it is incorrect in the context of the administration of a trust because the most important criterion for avoiding liability is the degree of attention to the decision-making process demonstrated by the trustee. See also Administration of Trusts in Florida § 2.2.Duty of ImpartialityImpartiality is another individual duty. The trustee must treat all beneficiaries fairly. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0803. See also Administration of Trusts in Florida § 2.5. Fairly, however, does not mean equally as different beneficiaries may have different needs. The trustee must give due consideration to the respective interests of the current beneficiaries and the remainder beneficiaries. For example, a current beneficiary may request a significant distribution. Justifying that the distribution is prudent (e.g., it is needed to pay the tuition for a beneficiary to attend law school and enhance the beneficiary's earning potential), however, if the distribution constitutes a significant percentage of the trust, it may unduly favor the current beneficiaries to the detriment of the remaindermen.That said, a client may wish to favor all current beneficiaries to the detriment of the interests of the remainder beneficiaries or one of the current beneficiaries to the detriment of other current beneficiaries. The estate planner may incorporate specific language in the trust instrument to permit for such preferences. For example, a trust instrument could include the following provision:Without limiting the Trustee's discretion, the Trustee may consider the needs of the Settlor's daughter as more important than the needs of other descendants of the Settlor, and the Settlor encourages the Trustee to be liberal in making distributions to the Settlor's daughter, even to the extent of distributing the entire trust principal.In a traditional trust that requires the trustee to distribute all of the trust income, the current beneficiaries may request that the trustee invest in assets that generate significant income, whereas the remainder beneficiaries would prefer the trustee invest in assets that have greater potential for appreciation. Historically, trustees have addressed the need to balance these competing interests by investing in a mixture of fixed income instruments and equities. However, modern portfolio theory deems this balanced approach inefficient and instead encourages the trustee to maximize or minimize expected return consistent with risk tolerance.Nevertheless, in a point that is widely misunderstood by beneficiaries and trustees similarly, the results of asset allocation do not dictate the trustee's distribution decisions. In other words, if a hypothetical balanced portfolio of 50% fixed income and 50% equities generates 2% annual income, however, the actual investment portfolio of the trust produces only 1.5% return, the trustee could justifiably use the power of adjustment to increase distributions to the current beneficiaries to 2% however, should not increase those distributions to 4%. Similarly, with respect to the trustee's duty of impartiality, it would be inappropriate for the trustee to invest primarily for income and distribute a windfall to the current beneficiaries.Duty to Keep Beneficiaries InformedIn theory, the duty to keep beneficiaries informed does not seem complex. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0813. See also Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.07[6]. The trustee ought to send periodic statements to the beneficiaries so they are aware of the assets held in the trust and the transactions that are occurring in the trust's account. That way, the beneficiaries can fulfill their fundamental role of enforcing the proper administration of the trust. So how does the attorney advise a client who does not want his or her children to learn about significant wealth being held in trust for their benefit so they do not lose all incentive to be productive members of society? The short answer is that, in Florida, there is not much that a trustee can do to shield this information from the beneficiaries because secrecy would constitute a breach of the trustee's fiduciary duty. A few states, however, such as Delaware and South Dakota, permit so-called silent trusts. See Del. Code Ann., tit. 30, §§ 3303 and 3339 and S.D. Codified Laws § 55-2-13.  In accordance with these statutes, the trustee may be relieved of any obligation to inform the beneficiaries of the existence of the trust or various aspects of the trust, and may be prohibited from voluntarily releasing such information. Professionals can speculate whether this is good public policy, however, certainly parents may have a valid concern. While it may be prudent to advise your client to have discussions with his or her children regarding the management of this wealth in accordance with expectations for being productive members of society, it would not be irrational to advise a concerned client to establish the trust in a state that respects silent trusts.Other DutiesThere remain a few additional individual duties that arguably come within the purview of those previously discussed yet warrant separate examination. The duty to administer the trust is one such duty. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0801; see also Kritchman v. Wolk, 152 So. 3d 628, 632 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 3d Dist. 2014) (holding that co-trustees breached their fiduciary duties by failing to carry out the terms of the trust to pay for a beneficiary's expenses to attend a university.) While this seems obvious, it may differ in the context of other fiduciary duties where there may not be an affirmative duty to act. See also Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.08.A second duty is the obligation to act within the scope of the trustee's authority. The trustee must be authorized to take an action (e.g., if the trust does not authorize distribution to a particular beneficiary until age 21, the trustee has no authority to make distributions earlier than that time). However, reexamining the duty of care, whether a trustee can take an action is only the first part of the analysis. Equally important is whether the trustee should take a proposed action. For example, the trust may authorize the trustee to invest the entire trust corpus in high yield bonds or a beneficiary's start-up business, however, either extreme is seldom prudent. Similarly, the trustee may have the authority to distribute all of the trust assets to the beneficiary, however, if the beneficiary is financially irresponsible, a distribution of all of the trust assets to the beneficiary is probably a poor decision.Responsibilities of TrusteeWhen administering a trust, the terms of the trust instrument, identity of the beneficiaries, nature of the trust assets, law governing the trust, tax status of the trust, and other circumstances all influence what specific tasks the trustee must undertake. Rarely will two different trust administrations be identical. Nevertheless, there are a few basic responsibilities that will generally apply to all trustees:• Trustees are required to take control of the trust assets. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0809. Trustees must maintain the trust assets separately and avoid commingling with such assets with their own personal assets. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0810(2). Fortunately, trustees may employ financial firms to hold investable assets (see Fla. Stat. § 736.0816(20)) and need not maintain certificated securities in a safe, which used to be commonplace.• Trustees are required to safeguard trust assets. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0809. For example, trustees should exercise prudence when choosing a custodian. See, e.g., Fla. Stat. § 736.0816(21)(b). Trustees should also properly insure real estate or artwork owned by the trust. See, e.g., Fla. Stat. § 736.0816(12).• Trustees are required to maintain clear, distinct, and accurate records for the trust. Fla. Stat. § 736.0810(1). Indeed, it is in the trustee's best interest to be an assiduous record keeper because if a beneficiary requests the trustee to submit an accounting of the trust administration, and the trustee lacks sufficient information to properly and fully account, the beneficiaries and the court may infer negative inferences that the trustee cannot rebut. See, e.g., Traub v. Traub, 135 So.2d 243, 244 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2d Dist. 1961) ("If the trustee fails to keep clear, distinct, and accurate accounts, all presumptions are against him and all obscurities and doubts are to be taken adversely to him.") As part of this responsibility, the trustee may need to track income and principal separately, particularly where the trust has different standards for income and principal distributions.• As fiduciaries, trustees are required to invest the assets of the trust. See Fla. Stat. § 518.11. However, trustees may delegate investment discretion to professional investment managers so long as they exercise reasonable care, skill, and caution in selecting the agent; establish the scope and terms of the delegation, consistent with the purposes and terms of the trust; and review the agent's actions periodically to monitor performance and compliance with the terms of the delegation. See Fla. Stat. § 518.112(1) and Fla. Stat. § 736.0807(1).• Trustees are required to make distributions that are mandated under the trust instrument. They must also consider beneficiaries' requests for discretionary distributions when the trust instrument vests the trustee with such discretion.• Trustees must file any tax returns that are required for the trust. This can be a somewhat complicated undertaking. A trust may not have a separate filing obligation under federal law if it is a grantor trust, though depending upon the circumstances, the trustee of a grantor trust may have an obligation to file an informational return. See I.R.C. §§ 671 through 679 and I.R.C. § 6048. In terms of state filing obligations, similar to individuals, trusts may have income sourced in different states and may have to file non-resident returns in those states. Moreover, because some states classify trusts as residents based on different criteria (i.e., residence of the trustee and/or residence of the beneficiaries), a trust may be a resident of multiple states. For example, a trust established by a Florida settlor with a Delaware trustee and a California beneficiary may have to file in all three states. Additionally, if there are any international aspects to the trust, an additional set of reporting obligations may apply. For these reasons attorneys should advise their trustee clients to retain accountants who have experience preparing fiduciary income tax returns, not just personal income tax returns or business entity returns.• Trustees may be required to pursue claims on behalf of the trust (e.g., against service providers, former trustees, or even co-trustees) or defend claims against the trust. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0811. See also, Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.07.Directed TrustsFlorida by statute permits directed trusts, where, for example, a co-trustee (a general trustee) designated in the trust instrument is vested with discretion over investments or distributions, as the case may be, and the role of another co-trustee (an administrative or excluded trustee) is merely to effectuate the directions it receives from the co-trustee or other designated advisors. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0703(9). So long as the excluded trustee does not participate in willful misconduct, that trustee is not responsible for any consequence that results from compliance with the exercise of the power and does not have a duty or an obligation to review, inquire, investigate, or make recommendations or evaluations with respect to the exercise of the power. Id.Unless otherwise specified in the trust instrument, multiple trustees who are unable to reach a unanimous decision may act by majority decision. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0703(1).Liability of TrusteeFla. Stat. § 736.1001(2) empowers the court to remedy a breach of trust in numerous ways, including any of the following:• Compelling the trustee to perform the trustee's duties• Enjoining the trustee from committing a breach of trust• Compelling the trustee to redress a breach of trust by paying money or restoring property or by other means• Ordering a trustee to account• Appointing a special fiduciary to take possession of the trust property and administer the trust• Suspending the trustee• Removing the trustee as provided in Fla. Stat. § 736.0706(2)• Reducing or denying compensation to the trustee• Subject to Fla. Stat. § 736.1016, voiding an act of the trustee, imposing a lien or a constructive trust on trust property, or tracing trust property wrongfully disposed of and recovering the property or its proceeds• Ordering any other appropriate reliefSee also 55A Fla Jur Trusts § 235.A trustee who commits a breach of trust is liable for the greater of:• The amount required to restore the value of the trust property and trust distributions to what such would have been if the breach had not occurred, including lost income, capital gain, or appreciation that would have resulted from proper administration –or–• The profit the trustee made by reason of the breachSee Fla. Stat. § 736.1002(1).Generally, trustees are not personally liable for the acts of a predecessor and successor trustees do not have a duty to institute a proceeding or file any claim against any prior trustee or that trustee's estate, for any of the prior trustee's actions. See Fla. Stat. § 736.08125(1).If the settlor is particularly concerned about reducing the trustee's liability, the trust instrument may include language exonerating a successor trustee for failing to seek redress. For example, the trust instrument could include the following provision:No Trustee shall be liable at any time by reason of, or in consequence of, any acts, omissions or defaults with respect to the administration of the trust by any predecessor trustee, and no Trustee shall have any duty to examine the accounts, records and acts of any predecessor trustee or to institute any action or claim against any predecessor trustee to compel redress of any breach of trust or for any other reason.In contrast, trustees will generally be held liable for actions of a co-trustee even if they do not participate in those actions, if they knew or should have known of such actions unless they notify the co-trustee(s) of their dissent at or before the time of the action. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0703(8). See also Administration of Trusts in Florida § 18.31. Even dissenting in writing will not, however, absolve a trustee of liability for failure to prevent a breach of trust or a failure to administer the trust. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0703(7).Compensation of TrusteeTrustees are entitled to commissions for administering trusts. See, e.g., Muscogee Lumber Co. v. Hyer, 18 Fla. 698, 703-704 (Fla. 1882); Traub v. Traub, 135 So.2d 243, 244 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2d Dist. 1961). "If the terms of a trust do not specify the trustee's compensation, a trustee is entitled to compensation that is reasonable under the circumstances." Fla. Stat. § 736.0708(1). If the terms of a trust agreement do specify the trustee's compensation, the court may still make adjustments, such as when the trustee's duties are substantially different from those contemplated at trust formation, or the specified compensation would be unreasonably low or high. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0708(2). The court's right to adjust the trustee's compensation is a mandatory provision which cannot be altered by the terms of the trust. See Fla. Stat. § 736.0105(2)(q). See also Florida Estates Practice Guide § 39.11.Borrowing from Bogert, Trusts and Trustees, § 976, the Florida Supreme Court has indicated that the following factors should be considered in determining the reasonableness of a trustee's compensation, namely:• The amount of capital and income received and disbursed by the trustee• The wages or salary customarily granted to agents or servants for performing like work in the community• The success or failure of the administration of the trustee• Any unusual skill or experience which the trustee in question may have brought to his work• The fidelity or disloyalty displayed by the trustee• The amount of risk and responsibility assumed• The time consumed in carrying out the trust• The custom in the community as to allowances to trustees by settlors or courts and as to charges exacted by trust companies and banks• The character of the work done in the course of administration, whether routine or involving skill and judgment• Any estimate which the trustee has given of the value of his own services• Payments made by a beneficiary to the trustee and intended to be applied toward his compensationSee West Coast Hospital Ass'n v. Florida National Bank, 100 So. 2d 807, 811 (Fla. 1958).It is standard practice for corporate trustees to charge commissions at the published rate schedules of trustees unless there is an agreement to the contrary.Current as of: 03/31/2025End of Document

Letter to Client 
[name of law firm][law firm address][law firm phone number][month] [day], [year][name of client][address]RE: Funding of Revocable TrustDear [name of client(s)]:FUNDING YOUR REVOCABLE TRUSTNow that you have established your Revocable Trust ("Trust"), it must be funded by transferring ownership of some or all of your assets to the Trust. If you own any assets jointly and undividedly with one or more persons and wish to transfer those assets into your Trust, all co-owners must join in the conveyance. Please note that this letter is not intended as tax advice. You should consult your tax professional regarding the tax consequences of funding the trust with each type of asset.This memorandum provides a general description of the steps necessary to transfer different kinds of assets to your Trust. Of course, the specific steps to accomplish this transfer will depend on the nature of the asset involved. If you would like assistance with any of these transfers, please contact my office. I can assist you in the asset transfer process, including the preparation of deeds and obtaining and filing necessary documentation.Please examine your assets to determine which assets to transfer into your Trust. The types of assets that may be transferred include stocks, bonds, real property located in any state or country, mineral and royalty interests, tangible personal property, bank accounts, brokerage accounts, certificates of deposit, corporate or partnership interests, outstanding notes, and any other type of ownership interests you may hold. Assets that generally should not be transferred to the trust during your lifetimes include retirement accounts, annuities, and life insurance policies. It is possible to name your Trust as beneficiary of these assets, but you should consult with a tax professional before changing the beneficiary designations of annuities and retirement accounts to avoid unintended tax consequences.In general, to transfer assets to your Trust, you will need to change the title for each asset from your names individually or as a co-owner to the Trust, as follows:[name of client 1] and [name of client 2] as TRUSTEES of the [name of Revocable Living Trust], dated [month] [day], [year]One of the major goals accomplished by a Trust as the main instrument in your estate plan is to avoid probate of the assets at the time of your deaths. To avoid probate, it is critically important that the Trust owns the assets, which are controlled by the serving trustee, and not by your individual and/or joint names, as outlined above. Although your pour-over Will directs the executor to add assets held in your individual name at your death to the trust assets to distribute as provided in your Trust Agreement, those assets will be subject to probate before they are added to the trust property. To avoid that result, you may wish to retitle all assets in the name of your Trust as outlined above.You should carefully and continually review the assets held in your own names (both assets that you now own and any that you acquire later) to be certain that this is consistent with your estate planning goals. I am available to discuss the advisability of retaining ownership of various assets in your name alone, holding assets in co-ownership with another person, or transferring assets to your Trust. On the following pages, I offer some general guidance on transferring specific types of assets to your Trust. These comments are general in nature, and for specific guidance, please contact my office.Accounts or Certificates Issued by a Bank or Other Savings Institution. The name on the account or certificate must be changed to reflect its ownership by the Trustee, and a new passbook or certificate must be issued in the name of the Trustee. Be careful to confirm with the financial institution before transferring a savings certificate that there will be no penalty for early withdrawal.Brokerage Accounts. If you own stocks, bonds, or other securities through a brokerage account, the brokerage firm's name and records must be changed to indicate that the Trustee owns the account on behalf of your Trust, and you do not own it individually. This also applies if the certificates for those assets are not issued in your name but are held instead in a street name or in the brokerage firm's name.Corporate Stocks (Issued by Publicly or Privately Held Corporations) or Mutual Fund Shares. If certificates are issued in your name, both individual or jointly, new certificates must be issued to reflect the Trustee's ownership of the stock or shares. You may be able to combine all certificates representing shares in one corporation into one new certificate, but you may wish to consider requesting a series of new certificates, one corresponding to each old certificate, to trace your income tax basis if any shares are sold by the Trustee during your lifetimes.Registered Bonds or Debentures (Issued by Publicly or Privately Held Corporations, the U.S. Government, an Agency, any State, or Subdivision thereof). These securities must also be registered in the name of the Trustee and new bonds or debentures reissued. As with stock certificates discussed above, for bonds or debentures held in a brokerage account, title to the account must be changed.Unregistered or Bearer Bonds or Debentures. These securities, typically issued by the United States government, an agency, a state, or a municipality, generally cannot be registered in the name of the Trustee, so that there must be some other evidence that these securities have been transferred. You may execute and deliver to the Trustee an Assignment to Revocable Trust, listing the bearer securities for transfer. The Trustee should retain the assignment with the permanent records of the Trust. I can prepare any documents necessary to accomplish the transfer. I recommend keeping bearer securities in a safe-deposit box in the name of the Trustee with a duplicate copy of the transfer document attached.Tangible Investment Assets (Such as Gold Bullion, Silver Coins, Art Objects). Because there is often no proof of registration or ownership of these assets, their transfer to your Trust should be handled in a manner similar to that described for unregistered securities. Any new investments of this type should be purchased directly in the name of the Trustee with the confirmation or other purchase slip retained with the instrument or investment to prove the Trustee's ownership.Partnership Interests (Whether in a General Partnership or Limited Partnership) and Other Business Interests. Business interests include, but may not be limited to, S Corporations, Limited Liability Companies (LLCs), Partnerships, and similar entities. Prior to transferring any business interest into your Trust, you should meet with a tax professional to ensure that corporate documents and relevant tax law allow for such a transfer. It is also important to understand if there are any specific tax consequences resulting from such a transfer.To register partnership interests in the Trustee's name, partners may need to execute a new certificate of partnership interest or an amendment to the partnership agreement. There may be restrictions against transfer in the partnership agreement, so it should be reviewed before the transfer is attempted.Interests in Real Property (Personal Residence, Investment Real Estate, and Mineral and Royalty Interests). Legal title must be transferred to the Trustee via an executed, notarized, and recorded deed.  In Louisiana, the trust instrument or an extract of trust (also known as Certification of Trust) should be recorded with the deed to a trust. Louisiana law allows for either the entire trust instrument or an extract to be filed along with the conveyance instrument. However, there will be times when a third party may request the entire Trust Agreement or additional terms of the Trust. Be careful to determine whether any existing mortgage or deed of trust secured by the transferred real estate will be affected by the proposed transfer and whether the proposed transfer will trigger any "due on sale" clause in the mortgage or deed of trust.  It is important to comply carefully with the requirements of the law of the state where the property is located. You may wish to consult with a title agent to ensure that the property interest is eligible for transfer. Ownership of oil, gas, and mineral rights may involve leases, royalties, or a working interest in the profits of production from real property. It is important to understand the nature of ownership prior to transferring ownership to a trust.Life Insurance Policies, Annuities, and Retirement Plan Benefits. Ownership of these assets generally may not be transferred to a revocable trust, but the death benefits can be made payable to the Trustee for distribution under the terms of the trust. Although life insurance policies generally pass outside of a succession, you may wish to transfer ownership to your Trust to give the Trustee more control over the policies in case you become disabled.Ownership of an Individual Retirement Account (IRA) and other retirement accounts should not transfer to the trust. Change-of-beneficiary forms from the insurance company or the administrator of the retirement plan must be completed and recorded with the insurer or the plan to name the Trustee of your Trust as the beneficiary of any benefits. Some annuities do not permit transfers and others have negative tax consequences if put into the Trust, so caution and consultation with your tax professional is advised.Once an asset transfers to the Trust, all transactions regarding that asset must be managed by the acting Trustee. For example, after corporate stock has been transferred to the Trustee on behalf of the Trust, the Trustee holds the power to sell, mortgage, or assign those shares of stock or to vote them at a shareholders' meeting. Any document evidencing the transfer of assets must be signed by the Trustee.Additional assets, including assets acquired in the future, may be transferred to your Trust either by registering them in the name of the Trustee on behalf of the Trust, by delivering them to the Trustee with appropriate documents to re-register the assets in the name of your Trust, or with other transfer documents if the asset is of the nonregistered type. Withdrawals of property from your Trust must comply with the provisions of the Trust Agreement. I can prepare documents for you to accomplish such a withdrawal. The Trust Agreement may be amended or revoked in its entirety, but any amendment or revocation must comply with the procedural requirements of the Trust Agreement and applicable state law.Please call me if you have any questions about the transfer of property to your Trust or about the operation of the Trust in the future. This memorandum is for your general guidance only and does not encompass all possible situations.
Sincerely yours,____________________[name of attorney]End of Document

Estate Plan for Single Individual Resource Kit (TX)
Go to: Initial Client Meeting   |   Wills   |   Trusts   |   Disability Planning   |   Powers of Attorney   |   Miscellaneous Documents & Client LettersMaintainedThis resource kit provides guidance on creating an estate plan for a single individual residing in Texas. An estate plan is defined as an arrangement providing for the use, management, investment, conservation, and transfer of an individual's property during his or her lifetime or after death. The documents used by counsel in creating an estate plan will vary depending on the client's circumstances, family needs, estate size, and wishes, among other things. For example, there may be reasons for a client to create a trust on behalf of his or her beneficiaries rather than gift assets outright to them, or vice versa. In addition to wills and trusts, there may be a need for medical powers of attorney, financial powers of attorney, or various other estate planning tools. This resource kit includes Practical Guidance materials on these potential options, including detailed practice notes, templates, and checklists.Initial Client MeetingMost estate planning matters begin with information gathering at or immediately before the initial client meeting. The details shared by the client at the beginning of the matter help to determine the appropriate and best estate planning tools for him or her. It is crucial for counsel to ascertain a client's objectives as well as estate information, and it is good practice to seek out this information prior to the initial client meeting by way of an estate planning questionnaire. An estate planning questionnaire will inquire into the client's assets; personal information about things like his or her children, citizenship, any prior marriage, etc.; and his or her desired fiduciaries.The following Practical Guidance resources will guide you through the early stages of crafting an estate plan for your client:Go to table1WillsOnce the client's estate planning objectives are ascertained and the necessary information is gathered, the attorney must consider the proper tools to carry out those objectives. In many instances, more than one estate planning tool can be used to achieve a desired objective. A will is the most basic tool in the estate planner's kit. A will enables the client to designate how his or her assets should be distributed after death and who should oversee that process. A will may also address certain post-death concerns, such as caring for a minor child. You must remember that this tool works only for assets held in the client's name alone and the client's ownership portion of jointly owned assets.The following Practical Guidance resources will guide you through drafting a will or a codicil for your client:Go to table2TrustsA trust is a legal arrangement pursuant to which a grantor or settlor transfers property to a trustee to administer on behalf of one or more beneficiaries in accordance with the terms of the governing instrument. The trustee is the legal owner of the trust assets and is tasked with administering them but does so only on behalf of the beneficiaries. Although trusts can be classified according to a number of criteria, the most important to note are inter vivos trusts or living trusts, which go into effect during the grantor's lifetime and can be either revocable or irrevocable, and testamentary trusts, which go into effect after the grantor dies. There are several reasons why a client may want to include a trust in his or her estate plan (e.g., avoid probate, hold out of state property, plan for future incapacity, seek out tax benefits, and/or keep asset information private).The following Practical Guidance resources will guide you through drafting or amending a trust for your client:Go to table3Disability PlanningA comprehensive estate plan will likely include provisions outlining what should take place in the event of a client's disability. A medical power of attorney can be used to authorize a health care agent to make medical or other health care decisions on an individual's behalf. A living will is an advance health care directive that details the medical measures a person does or does not want taken in a variety of potential circumstances. Both instruments serve to ensure an individual's health-care wishes are followed if he or she cannot enforce those decisions due to a disability or other circumstance. In addition, certain clients may benefit from guidance concerning elder law planning.The following Practical Guidance resources will provide more information and guide you through this aspect of a client's estate plan:Go to table4Powers of AttorneyPowers of attorney are often included as part of a client's estate plan. A power of attorney is the legal instrument by which an individual (the principal) authorizes another individual (the attorney-in-fact or agent) to make certain business, financial, and personal decisions on his or her behalf.The following Practical Guidance resources will provide more information on powers of attorney:Go to table5Miscellaneous Documents & Client LettersDepending on your client's circumstances, a comprehensive estate plan may warrant the preparation of additional documents, such as one detailing the client's wishes for the disposition of their remains or a revocable transfer on death deed. While these are not always included in a standard estate plan, many practitioners incorporate them when they are relevant to the client's situation.The following Practical Guidance resources can be used to supplement a client's estate planning package:  Go to table6Current as of: 06/10/2025

Letter to Client 
Table of Contents
Dear [name of client]:I am writing regarding the [name of Donor] Charitable Lead Unitrust dated [month] [day], [year] (the "Trust"), which we [have prepared / reviewed upon your request].The purpose of this letter is to (1) describe the process of transferring assets into the trust; and (2) discuss what you, as trustee of the Trust, need to address during administration of the Trust. Please keep this letter for future reference.To accomplish the long-term goals for which the trust was created, the trustee must adhere to the terms in the trust document and the tax laws relating to trusts. If you have any questions about the tax laws relating to this trust, please do not hesitate to ask me or the person who prepares the tax returns for the Trust.The Trust describes the powers and duties of the trustee(s). Since not all trust documents (also called trust instruments) contain the same powers, closely review and familiarize yourself with the Trust terms to be certain of your authority, requirements imposed upon you, and options for taking action on behalf of the Trust. Reach out to me with questions about the Trust terms as you review them.The Trust is a Charitable Remainder Annuity Trust, which is designed to provide a stream of income to a donor or designated beneficiary as a fixed amount with the remaining funds being distributed to a charitable entity. Transfers to the Trust can consist of cash, bonds, shares of stock, intellectual property, or real property that is not lived in by the grantor, etc. It is important to make sure that the assets transferred to the trust will provide enough income for the required distributions.1. Irrevocability of Trust. The trust is an irrevocable trust and cannot be amended, except under limited circumstances to conform with federal or state law. Please contact me if you believe this may be an issue at any time during the administration of the trust.2. Federal Tax Identification Number. Since the trust is a non-grantor trust, you must obtain a taxpayer identification number (TIN) for the Trust from the Internal Revenue Service by filing IRS Form SS-4 or going onto irs.gov and obtaining one online. The TIN serves to keep the trust assets separate from those of the grantor and identifies the trust in bank accounts and tax returns.3. Funding the Trust. The ownership of one or more assets must be transferred to the trustee for the trust to be in effect. Simply listing assets in Schedule A of the trust or describing the assets to be transferred to the trust anywhere in the document does not fund the trust. The bank or brokerage account or the asset itself, such as shares of stock, should be titled in the name of the trust, as follows: "[Name of trustee], Trustee of The [name of Donor] Charitable Remainder Annuity Trust dated [month] [day] [year]." (Some banks may want to use a slightly different name.)To transfer funds from checking, savings, and brokerage accounts, the TIN should be provided. A bank or brokerage firm may request a copy of the signed trust instrument for examination by the firm's legal department. We generally do not provide a copy of the entire agreement. A copy of the signature page and the trustee powers will serve to demonstrate that the trust has been properly executed, and the trustee has the necessary power to borrow money, buy and sell stocks, bonds, and options, trade on margin, and conduct other trust business. A certification of trust prepared in accordance with [state] law may also sometimes be used in lieu of the entire trust agreement.To transfer real estate, a deed must be executed and recorded granting the property to the trust. We can prepare the deed for the property for signature by the donor. Upon obtaining the necessary signatures, we will record the deed at the county Recorder of Deeds office. You should contact the homeowner's insurance company to notify them of the title change.4. Administration of the Trust. (a) Taxation of Trust Income. File the IRS form 5227, IRS Form 1041, and [state] income tax forms to report the income for any year in which the trust has taxable income. These forms are due on April 15 of the year after receipt of the taxable income. We strongly recommend retaining an accountant for preparation of tax returns.(b) State Requirement. Register the trust with the [State] Attorney General if it is required for a charitable trust.(c) Distributions from the Trust. The Trust was created to provide [designated recipient] an Annuity Trust amount equal to [number representing the annual Annuity Trust percentage to be paid to the designated recipient]% of the net fair market value of the assets of the trust, valued as of the trust's initial value.If you have any questions about permissible distributions, please do not hesitate to contact me.(d) Recordkeeping. Please keep detailed records of the trust assets, income, and expenditures (including the date, amount, payee, and purpose). You may be required to provide a detailed accounting of the Trust to the trust beneficiaries on a yearly basis and upon the termination of the Trust.5. Termination of the Trust. The trust will terminate if any of the following events occur:(a) There are no more assets in the trust.(b) The unitrust period terminates.6. Trustee Powers. A detailed list of the trustee's powers can be found in Paragraph [paragraph number] of the trust. Please make sure you understand them. I am happy to answer any questions you may have about them.I hope that this letter has answered your immediate questions. If you would like further explanation of any aspect of funding or administering the trust, please do not hesitate to contact me.
Sincerely,____________________[Name of attorney]End of Document

Letter to Financial Institution 
[date][Name of Financial Institution][Financial Institution Address]Re: Account Number(s): [Account Number(s)]Dear Sir or Madam:  [I [if your client is single] (or) We [if client is married]] wish to change the title of all of [my [if client single] (or) our [if married]] banking and brokerage accounts (other than any IRA accounts). Please change the owner of each account to the following:[Name of Trustee(s)], as Trustee(s) of [name of Trust], U/A dated [date].Please find a copy of a Certification of Trust which documents the establishment of [my or our, if the client is married] trust and sets out the powers for the future handling of the account by the Trustee. Please continue to use the Social Security Number (SSN) now on the account as the Tax Identification Number; pursuant to IRS Regulation 1.671-4(b), no separate Tax Identification Number is required for this type of trust.If you have any questions regarding this transfer, please contact [me or us, if client is marred] at the address below, [address] or via telephone at [telephone number of client]. Thank you for your cooperation.Sincerely yours,_______________[Client's name]_______________[Client's name]__________________[Address 1]__________________[Address 2]__________________[City, State ZIP]End of Document

Revocation of Trust 
Revocation of TrustThe parties have previously created a revocable trust dated [date], naming [names of beneficiaries] as beneficiaries and [name(s)] as Trustee[s]. A copy of the trust instrument is attached to this Agreement as Exhibit A.and is incorporated by reference. The parties now revoke the trust and agree that the remaining trust property shall be [specify disposition].
Dated: ____________________________________ Settlor name and signatureDated: ____________________________________ Beneficiary name and signatureDated: ____________________________________ Attorney-in-fact name and signatureNOTARY ACKNOWLEDGMENTGo to table1Go to table2  On ____________________, 20__, before me,__________________________________, a notary public in and for the State of California, personally appeared __________________, who proved to me on the basis of satisfactory evidence to be the person whose name(s) is/are subscribed to the within instrument and acknowledged to me that he/she/they executed the same in his/her/their authorized capacity(ies), and that by his/her/their signature(s) on the instrument the person(s), or the entity upon behalf of which the person acted, executed the instrument.  I certify under PENALTY OF PERJURY under the laws of the State of California that the foregoing paragraph is true and correct.WITNESS my hand and official seal.____________________________________(Seal)

Certificate of Trust 
After recording, return to:[name of attorney or settlor to whom recorded certificate is being returned][Address of attorney or settlor]CERTIFICATE OF TRUSTPURSUANT TO MASSACHUSETTS GENERAL LAW CHAPTER 184, SECTION 35FOR THE[NAME OF TRUST]KNOW THAT, [settlor name], having an address at [settlor address], as Settlor, created a revocable trust, known as the [name of trust] dated [month] [day], [year] by executing a Declaration of Trust, dated [month] [day], [year] naming [trustee name] having an address at [trustee address], as trustee(s) (referred to as the "Trustee"). If [settlor name] dies, resigns, becomes incapacitated or otherwise unable or unwilling to serve as Trustee of said Declaration of Trust, then [successor trustee 1], having an address at [successor trustee 1 address], and [successor trustee 2], having an address at [successor trustee address 2], shall serve as successor trustees (collectively referred to as a "successor Trustee").This Certificate of Trust is executed as evidence of the existence of the foregoing Declaration of Trust. Any person may rely upon this Certificate of Trust as evidence of the existence of said Declaration of Trust and is relieved of any obligation to verify that any transaction entered into by a Trustee or successor Trustee thereunder is consistent with the terms and conditions of said Declaration of Trust. The Declaration of Trust has not been revoked, amended or modified in any manner that would result in the representations contained in this Certificate of Trust to be false or incorrect. Furthermore, there have been no amendments limiting the powers of the Trustee of said Declaration of Trust.The Declaration of Trust provides that the Trustee shall have all of the powers and authority granted to trustees by statute or common law in any jurisdiction in which the Trustee may act, including, but not limited to, all powers and authorities set forth in Chapter 203E, Section 816 of the Massachusetts General Laws and by any future amendments thereto, except for any instance in which such powers and authorities may conflict with the express provisions of the Declaration of Trust, in which case the express provisions of the Declaration of Trust shall control. In addition to such powers, the Trustee is specifically authorized: [additional powers set forth in Declaration of Trust].The Declaration of Trust and the trusts created thereunder may be referred to by the name: "[living trust name] dated [month] [day], [year]." Any transfers to the Declaration of Trust or any trust thereunder may refer to the aforesaid name or to "[trustee name] as Trustee under [living trust name] dated [month] [day], [year]," with or without specifying any change in Trustee or any amendment to the Declaration of Trust.There are no further facts that serve as a condition precedent for the trustee's actions or that are otherwise relevant to the trust's matters.A copy of this Certificate of Trust shall be as valid as the original.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Settlor has executed this Certificate of Trust as of this [date] day of [month], [year].____________________[name of settlor]Settlor
COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS[county], ssOn this [date] day of [month], [year], before me, the undersigned notary public, personally appeared [settlor name], as Settlor, proved to me through satisfactory evidence of identification, which was [his/her/their] [identification], to be the person whose name is signed on the preceding or attached document, and who acknowledged that [he/she/they] signed it voluntarily for its stated purpose.____________________Notary Public____________________Print NameMy commission expires: ____________________End of Document

Letter to Client
